title: I’ve run 75+ businesses. Here’s why you’re probably chasing the wrong idea. | Andrew Wilkinson
key_insights: Choose boring, niche business ideas with less competition rather than glamorous markets everyone pursues
Fish where the fish are - find profitable niches with high willingness to pay and fewer competitors
Never hire someone thinking you can change them - hire for what you need, not potential
AI tools can replace many knowledge work tasks - use tools like Lindy to automate workflows and stay competitive
Money doesn't solve internal anxiety or depression - mental health medication had more impact on happiness than wealth
Focus on businesses with defensive moats like network effects, strong brands, or high switching costs
Bootstrap businesses can scale to hundreds of millions without venture capital if you choose the right model
Getting diagnosed and treated for ADHD is common among entrepreneurs and can dramatically improve work and personal life
topics_discussed: bootstrap vs venture capital funding decisions
replacing human assistants with AI agents
impact of AI on employment and jobs
memorable_quotes: Fish where the fish are - find a small fishing hole with lots of fish and very little competition
Easy choices, hard life. Hard choices, easy life
It's like having the world's most reliable employee who costs $200 a month and works 24/7
frameworks_mentioned: Charlie Munger's 'fish where the fish are' principle
Network effects and switching costs evaluation
recommended_for: business owners interested in AI automation
summary: Andrew Wilkinson, who has started 75+ businesses and built Tiny into a $300M holding company, shares tactical advice on finding profitable startup ideas in boring niches, using AI to automate work, and how addressing mental health issues impacted his happiness more than becoming a billionaire.
